Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: A low-cost real-time bio-electrochemical nitrate sensor for surface water monitoring
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project will continue the development of a low-cost real-time bio-electrochemical nitrate sensor for surface water monitoring initially funded as an NSF SBIR Phase I project. In Phase I, Cambrian Innovation demonstrated the feasibility of a bio-electrochemical sensor for measuring the level of nitrate in a water sample. Following the initial proof-of-principle, a microscale sensor prototype was developed and tested. The Phase II project will continue the development of the bio-electrochemical nitrate sensor to reach a detection level of less than 1 mg-N/L with a stable deployment of 6 months. Phase II development will optimize the sensor architecture and operational conditions for improved performance and develop a long-lasting substrate for microbial growth. Phase II will also include the design and construction of prototype electronic components, including the signal processing algorithm for interpreting the signal emitted by the bio-electrochemical cell. Finally, the sensor performance will be validated by extensive laboratory testing under controlled conditions followed by the initiation of field testing. Upon Phase II completion, Cambrian will be prepared for final development and testing of a first-generation nitrate sensor system in a Phase IIB project.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project addresses environmental nitrogen management, one of the most pressing issues facing society in the 21st century. Nitrate contamination of waterways has become a high profile topic due to anoxic dead zones and drops in fish populations. A significant portion of this environmental impact has been attributed to agricultural run-off (USGS, DOI, 2000). The need for regulation, monitoring, enforcement, and remediation of nitrate pollution is limited by a lack of cost-effective technology for continuous monitoring of nitrate in the environment. Simultaneously, an increased thrust in precision agriculture has been fueled not only by environmental concerns but also by the dramatic improvements in crop yield and quality that can be obtained through careful control of nutrient addition. The development of a low-cost real-time nitrate sensor will transform the management of agricultural facilities, resulting in dramatic improvements in fertilizing efficiency and the environmental impact of the food production industry. Cambrian Innovation is developing a bioelectrochemical nitrate sensor to fill this unmet need and establish a new paradigm in environmental sensing.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A Low-cost Real-time Bio-electrochemical Nitrate Sensor for Surface Water Monitoring

Technical Merits

Cambrian Innovation has developed a new technology for sensing nitrate in water. The sensor uses living microorganisms in a bio-electrochemical system (BES) to produce an electrochemical response, which displays a reduction in electrical current dependent on the concentration of nitrate. Specifically, the sensor leverages the biological regulation in microorganisms that result in the hierarchical use of the most energetically favorable terminal electron. Some electrically active microorganisms can be used to oxidize the organic materials and transport electrons outside of the cell to a terminal electron acceptor, such as oxygen and nitrate. If those electron acceptors are not present, the microbe respires to the electrodes, creating a measureable current through an external circuit. Meanwhile, when nitrate is present, the microbe preferentially respires to it and reduces the current through the electrodes.

This Phase II SBIR project focused on the development of this technology as a novel, low-cost, real-time bio-electrochemical nitrate sensor. The focus of the project was to assess several different methods for acquiring electrical data from the BES to develop methods for addressing key technical challenges associated with biological stability, develop sensor components (including suitable electrodes, electrolyte, and membranes), design and prototype electrical hardware, and test the components in a real world setting. Several key advancements were made to the biological techniques and the physical architecture that improved the sensitivity, response time, and accuracy of the sensor. By the end of the project, measurements could be made reliably on nitrate concentrations ranging from 1 to 100 mg-N/L, and a final demonstration on a real process water stream demonstrated the performance on an unknown and uncharacterized sample. The sensor also demonstrated high selectivity with no unexpected interferences to the signal. Prototype support hardware was developed under the project that met requirements under a target budget. Overall, the project was successful in establishing solutions to operational constraints, and the technology is now ready for design for manufacturing and commercial deployment.

Broader Impacts / Commercial Potential

Our patented sensor is an inexpensive, durable, and accurate tool for monitoring agencies, research institutions, watershed management organizations, and farmers concerned with monitoring and controlling nutrient run-off over large coverage areas. Monitoring nutrients such as nitrate has been an increasing focus as the world works to solve its environmental challenges and moves towards circular economy practices. Nitrate monitoring is needed in surface water produced at non-point sources such as agricultural operations and water treatment plants, as well as across watersheds more generally, to solve significant environmental and human health challenges. With real-time nitrate monitoring, farmers could minimize fertilizer applications, and regulators could quickly mitigate the impact of contaminated waterways.

The current practice for monitoring nitrate in surface water through periodic field testing and sampling is labor- and cost-intensive. Unfortunately, existing nitrate sensor technologies that could solve this pain point are expensive ($500 - $15,000 / sensor) and short-lived (average duration is 6 months). As a result, our project was focused on developing a solution to provide real-time results over an extended deployment at a minimal cost point (<$1,000).

The initial target applications of the bio-electrochemical nitrate sensor are in wastewater treatment processes and surface water monitoring. Both markets are in need of cost-effective, real-time data to drive operational and regulatory decisions. Dedicated to operational efficiency and data analytics, Cambrian Innovation is excited at the prospects of bringing the technology to the industrial wastewater treatment market to complement existing products in anaerobic and aerobic wastewater treatment.
